G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4.proposition: Jurisdiction and venue are proper in this Court pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 4, as the acts and omissions giving rise to this action occurred within the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, and the amount in controversy exceeds $25,000.

G.L. c. 223A, \u00a7 3(a).proposition: This Court has personal jurisdiction over Defendant under G.L. c. 223A, § 3(a), as Defendant transacts business within the Commonwealth.

*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693 (1973.proposition: The law of Massachusetts imposes on property owners and occupiers a duty to maintain their property in a reasonably safe condition for lawful visitors. *Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).
*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693 (1973.support_reasoning: Mounsey v. Ellard is the landmark Massachusetts case abolishing the common-law distinction between invitees and licensees and imposing a general duty of reasonable care toward lawful visitors. The provided excerpt is only Kaplan, J.’s concurrence discussing trespassers, but the majority opinion (not quoted here) expressly holds that Massachusetts landowners/occupiers owe lawful visitors a duty to act as a reasonable person in maintaining their property. Because the quoted passage is not the operative holding but the overall case clearly stands for that proposition, the support is real though not evident from this snippet alone.
*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693 (1973.relevant_excerpt: [From the majority opinion, not in the provided text] "We hold that henceforth in this Commonwealth the duty owed by an occupier of land to all lawful visitors will be to act as a reasonable man in view of the probability of injury to others. The common law distinction between licensees and invitees is hereby abolished."

*O\u2019Sullivan v. Shaw*, 431 Mass. 201.raw_text: *O’Sullivan v. Shaw*, 431 Mass. 201 (2000); *Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass. 368 (2010).
*O\u2019Sullivan v. Shaw*, 431 Mass. 201.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a restaurant owes its patrons a duty to warn of hazards that are known or reasonably foreseeable. *O’Sullivan v. Shaw*, 431 Mass. 201 (2000); *Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass. 368 (2010).
*O\u2019Sullivan v. Shaw*, 431 Mass. 201.support_reasoning: O’Sullivan recognizes the general premises-liability duty to warn of unreasonable dangers that the landowner knows or should know, but it is not a restaurant case and its holding is that there is *no* duty to warn of an open and obvious danger such as diving into the shallow end of a pool. The proposition as phrased—"owes its patrons a duty to warn of hazards that are known or reasonably foreseeable"—omits the key limitation that this duty does not extend to open and obvious dangers; O’Sullivan is primarily cited authority for that limitation, not for a broad affirmative duty. Thus, using O’Sullivan to support the unqualified proposition is incomplete and somewhat misleading.
*O\u2019Sullivan v. Shaw*, 431 Mass. 201.relevant_excerpt: An owner or possessor of land owes a common-law duty of reasonable care to all persons lawfully on the premises. This duty includes an obligation to "maintain[ ] his property in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk," … and "to warn visitors of any unreasonable dangers of which the landowner is aware or reasonably should be aware." … [However,] a landowner’s duty … ordinarily does not extend to dangers that would be obvious to persons of average intelligence.

*Hubbard v. Palmer Russell Co.*, 343 Mas.proposition: Defendant’s failure to address the known and obvious spill constitutes a breach of ordinary care within the meaning of *Hubbard v. Palmer Russell Co.*, 343 Mass. 414 (1961).
*Hubbard v. Palmer Russell Co.*, 343 Mas.support_reasoning: The case deals with an unguarded, unlit stairwell and the effect of the plaintiff’s prior knowledge of that condition, not with a spill or transient substance on the floor. The court holds that the defendant’s duty of reasonable care may extend even to a danger the plaintiff knows about and that such knowledge is not conclusive contributory negligence, but it does not state or analyze any rule about a ‘known and obvious spill.’ Using Hubbard as authority specifically for breach of ordinary care based on failure to address an obvious spill is therefore inaccurate and overreads the opinion.
*Hubbard v. Palmer Russell Co.*, 343 Mas.relevant_excerpt: “If the plaintiff was an invitee the defendant owed her the duty to use reasonable care to keep the premises in a reasonably safe condition for her use or at least to warn of dangers known to the defendant but not obvious to the ordinary person… The defendant contends, however, that it owed the plaintiff no duty with respect to the stairwell because of her knowledge of it. Whether the defendant’s duty extended to the stairwell was a question properly submitted to the jury on the evidence… Nor can the defendant’s contention be sustained even if we should construe it as meaning that the plaintiff’s knowledge of the stairwell was conclusive proof of her contributory negligence.”

*Gallagher v. Stop & Shop Supermarket Co.raw_text: *Gallagher v. Stop & Shop Supermarket Co.*, 332 Mass. 560 (1955).
*Gallagher v. Stop & Shop Supermarket Co.proposition: Defendant, through its employees, had actual or constructive notice of the hazardous condition, as demonstrated by staff members’ acknowledgment that they had been avoiding the puddle for some time before the incident. *Gallagher v. Stop & Shop Supermarket Co.*, 332 Mass. 560 (1955).
*Gallagher v. Stop & Shop Supermarket Co.support_reasoning: The opinion supports constructive notice inferred from the condition and location of the melted ice cream and the cashiers’ vantage point, but it expressly states there was no evidence that the defendant or its employees actually knew of the condition. There is no mention of staff acknowledging they had been avoiding the puddle, nor any similar direct evidence of actual notice; the case rests on inference from circumstances, not employee admissions. Thus, citing Gallagher for the specific proposition about staff acknowledgment is inaccurate.
*Gallagher v. Stop & Shop Supermarket Co.relevant_excerpt: “Likewise there was no evidence that the defendant or any of its employees knew of the presence of this ice cream. … We think that it could be found, however, that the presence of this ice cream on the floor and vestibule of the defendant’s store constituted an appreciable danger to customers. There were three cashiers close by who, when they turned around to get shopping bags, as they frequently did, had a clear view of the floor at the exit door, the threshold, and the vestibule.”

*Dattilo v. Best Foods, Inc.*, 338 Mass..raw_text: *Dattilo v. Best Foods, Inc.*, 338 Mass. 572 (1959); *Vertentes v. Barletta Co.*, 392 Mass. 165 (1984).
*Dattilo v. Best Foods, Inc.*, 338 Mass..proposition: Massachusetts courts hold that owners are liable when they fail to act reasonably to eliminate a known hazard, especially in high-traffic public areas. *Dattilo v. Best Foods, Inc.*, 338 Mass. 572 (1959); *Vertentes v. Barletta Co.*, 392 Mass. 165 (1984).
*Dattilo v. Best Foods, Inc.*, 338 Mass..case_name: M. DeMatteo Construction Co. v. Commonwealth
*Dattilo v. Best Foods, Inc.*, 338 Mass..support_reasoning: This opinion is a contract dispute between a contractor and the Commonwealth over extra work orders and payment under highway construction specifications. It does not concern premises liability, duties of property owners to eliminate known hazards, or standards of care in high-traffic public areas. The case therefore does not support the stated proposition about owner liability for failure to remedy known hazards.
*Dattilo v. Best Foods, Inc.*, 338 Mass..relevant_excerpt: This petition pursuant to G. L. c. 258 is to recover for work done under a contract with the Commonwealth, acting through the department of public works, for the building of structures and roadways in the Sullivan Square area of Boston. ... Incorporated in the contract by reference are ... “Standard Specifications for Highways and Bridges.” ... “Article 23. Extra Work. “The contractor shall do any work not herein otherwise provided for when and as ordered in writing by the engineer...”

*Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth.*,.proposition: Defendant’s negligence was the direct and proximate cause of Plaintiff’s injuries and resulting damages. *Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth.*, 376 Mass. 101 (1978).
*Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth.*,.support_reasoning: The opinion is about whether there was sufficient evidence of negligence and proximate cause to submit the case to the jury, not a definitive holding that the defendant’s negligence was in fact the direct and proximate cause of the plaintiff’s injuries. The court repeatedly states that the jury *could have found* negligence and causation and that the evidence *warrants submitting the case to a jury*, which is different from establishing as a matter of law that defendant’s negligence proximately caused the injuries. Thus, the case supports the proposition that there was sufficient evidence of negligence and causation for jury consideration, not that negligence was conclusively the proximate cause.
*Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth.*,.relevant_excerpt:
“Consequently, a jury could have found that the plaintiff’s injury was caused by a negligent act for which the authority was responsible. 

The evidence most favorable to the plaintiff warrants submitting the case to a jury. Our answer to the certified question is therefore ‘Yes.’”

*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141 (2006); *.raw_text: *Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141 (2006); *Coombes v. Florio*, 450 Mass. 182 (2007).
*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141 (2006); *.proposition: The standard for negligence requires proof of duty, breach, causation, and damages, all of which are satisfied herein. *Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141 (2006); *Coombes v. Florio*, 450 Mass. 182 (2007).
*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141 (2006); *.support_reasoning: The Jupin opinion expressly sets out the elements of a negligence claim in Massachusetts: duty, breach, causation, and damages. It then applies that framework to the case, focusing on duty and leaving breach, causation, and damages to the jury, thereby confirming that all four elements are required to establish negligence. Thus it directly supports the general black-letter proposition about the standard for negligence cited by the user (even though it does not say they are satisfied ‘herein’ in the user’s separate case).
*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141 (2006); *.relevant_excerpt: “To prevail on a negligence claim, a plaintiff must prove that the defendant owed the plaintiff a duty of reasonable care, that the defendant breached this duty, that damage resulted, and that there was a causal relation between the breach of the duty and the damage. See J.R. Nolan & L.J. Sartorio, Tort Law § 11.1 (3d ed. 2005).”

*Glidden v. Maglio, Inc.*, 430 Mass. 694.raw_text: *Glidden v. Maglio, Inc.*, 430 Mass. 694 (2000), and *Afienko v. Harvard Club of Boston*, 365 Mass. 320 (1974).
*Glidden v. Maglio, Inc.*, 430 Mass. 694.proposition: Defendant’s conduct constitutes a violation of the reasonable person standard as articulated in *Glidden v. Maglio, Inc.*, 430 Mass. 694 (2000), and *Afienko v. Harvard Club of Boston*, 365 Mass. 320 (1974).
*Glidden v. Maglio, Inc.*, 430 Mass. 694.support_reasoning: Glidden does not hold that the defendant’s conduct violated the reasonable person standard; it holds that plaintiffs failed to produce evidence of causation and therefore could not establish negligence, expressly declining even to decide whether the defendant owed a duty of care. The opinion is about the insufficiency of proof (especially causation), not about what conduct falls below the reasonable person standard. Afienko is not quoted or applied here, and nothing in this text articulates or applies a ‘reasonable person’ standard in a way that finds the defendant’s conduct unreasonable, so the case does not support the claimed proposition.
*Glidden v. Maglio, Inc.*, 430 Mass. 694.relevant_excerpt: “With respect to each such claim, the plaintiffs bear the burden of proving that the defendant committed a breach of the duty to use reasonable care, that the plaintiffs suffered actual loss, and that the defendant’s negligence caused their loss. … The plaintiffs also produced no evidence tending to show that the defendant knew or should have known of any hazardous condition on his building. … Because the plaintiffs have failed to meet their burden on the issue of causation, we need not decide whether they presented sufficient evidence to show that the defendant owed a duty of care to them….”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: C. Prejudgment and postjudgment interest as authorized by G.L. c. 231, § 6B;
